Description: Cast dome-shaped weight in copper alloy; carinated dome type; of truncated conical shape, with flat base and slightly convex top; complete; corroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Dome-shaped (or "cupcake-shaped") weights are the most common type found in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. XXIII, “domed” type), but also elsewhere in Egypt (Cour-Marty 1990, 25-26, fig. 4, fig. 13) and in the Near East (Birney and Levine 2011, 474). Bronze weights of this type seem, however, to be more often found on Phoenician sites (Kletter 1994, 36-37). In Naukratis, they are all small-sized, rather light, and are associated with various standards. Birney, K.J. and Levine, E. 2011, ‘Balance Weights’, in L.E. Stager, J.D. Schloen and D.M. Master, Ashkelon 3: The Seventh Century B.C. (Final reports of The Leon Levy Expedition to Ashkelon 3), 473–92. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1990, 'Les poids égyptiens, de précieux jalons archéologiques', Cahier de Recherches de l'Institut de Papyrologie et d'Egyptologie de Lille 12, 17-55. Kletter, R. 1994, ‘Phoenician(?) Weights from Ḥorvat Rosh Zayit’, ῾Atiqot 25, 33-43. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (VB.124) (phase 3)
